Those aren't the only two options. You can say that it was a true test, and that it failed in this situation, and that you also think it might succeed in another situation.

If you give a cancer patient chemo and they still die, you don't say it wasn't a true treatment -- you obviously gave them the real medicine. But, you also don't say that chemo doesn't work. You say it didn't work, but that it still might work for other patients.

user_message: A: If you build your economy around a break-even point you're going to have a shortfall if the point isn't reached, that's just a strict tautology. It can be a 'not as bad' shortfall if you have a diversified economy but you're still running a deficit. The overarching difference of Norway's wealth fund is that since they don't budget for what they are going to receive they are actually impervious to price fluctuations; they have no break-even point and that's why they don't appear on that chart.
ai_response: Until just a couple years ago, the Federal government controlled the price of raisins in the US by seizing a portion of farmers' crops each year. Amazingly, it took the Supreme Court striking down the program for it to stop.

ai_response: The Laffer Curve is entirely about government revenue. The principle in and of itself claims nothing about economic growth (although Laffer himself might make such claims for other reasons).
